title-group.article-title: Evidence-Based Analysis of the Efficacy for Operative Treatment of Hallux Rigidus

author-notes.corresp: Daniel S. McNeil, BSc, Dalhousie University, Faculty of Medicine, Queen Elizabeth II Health Sciences Center, Halifax Infirmary (Suite 4867), 1796 Summer Street, Halifax, NS, Canada, B3H 3A7 Email: danielmcneil@dal.ca

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: The aim of this article is to provide an evidence-based literature review and assessment of the quality of literature regarding operative interventions for hallux rigidus.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: A comprehensive evidence-based literature review of the PubMed database was conducted on June 24, 2011, identifying 586 articles, of which 135 were relevant in assessing the efficacy of common operative interventions for hallux rigidus. The 135 studies were then assigned a level of evidence (I-V) to denote quality. They were then reviewed to provide a grade of recommendation (A-C, I) in support of or against the operative intervention in treatment of hallux rigidus.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Based on the results of this evidence-based review, there is fair evidence (grade B) in support of arthrodesis for treatment of hallux rigidus. There is poor evidence (grade C) in support of cheilectomy, osteotomy, implant arthroplasty, resection arthroplasty, and interpositional arthroplasty for treatment of hallux rigidus. There is insufficient evidence (grade I) for cheilectomy with osteotomy for treatment of hallux rigidus.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: There are no consistent findings in comparative studies that are properly powered with validated and appropriate outcome measures to allow any definitive conclusions on which procedure is best. However, the grade B recommendation assigned to arthrodesis may make it the logical leading candidate for future high-quality randomized controlled trials. Clearly, further studies—ideally, high-quality Level I randomized controlled trials with validated outcome measures—are needed to allow stronger recommendations to be made.

sec.title: Level of Evidence:
sec.p: Level III, systematic review.

body.p: Hallux rigidus is a term used to describe arthritis of the first metatarsophalangeal joint. It is characterized by pain, which is usually worsened by walking, joint stiffness, and decreased range of motion, especially dorsiflexion. Patients presenting with hallux rigidus may initially be managed with nonoperative treatment, including but not limited to rocker-bottom shoes, stiff-soled shoes, wide-toe-box shoes, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, cortisone injection, analgesics, activity modification, and orthotics. When nonoperative measures fail to provide relief, operative intervention is indicated. Surgery can be joint sparing, such as cheilectomy or osteotomy, or joint sacrificing, such as arthrodesis or arthroplasty. The aim of this article was to provide an evidence-based literature review and assessment of the quality of literature regarding operative interventions for hallux rigidus.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A comprehensive literature review was conducted on June 24, 2011. A search of the PubMed database using terms to identify operative interventions (arthroplasty, arthrodesis, osteotomy, cheilectomy, osteophytectomy, exostectomy, surgery) for hallux rigidus (hallux rigidus, metatarsophalangeal joint, first metatarsophalangeal joint, arthritis) produced 586 articles. Non-English publications without an English translation were excluded, leaving 495 articles. The abstracts were reviewed to identify therapeutic studies examining the results of treatment. Studies involving mixed diagnoses were excluded if results specific to hallux rigidus cases were not discernible. A total of 135 studies were found to meet these criteria.

Each study to be included in this review was then assigned a level of evidence (I-V), in accordance with the standards of the Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery (Table 1).139 The literature was reviewed, and a grade of recommendation (A-C, I) was assigned to each intervention of interest, based on the revised classifications of Wright (Table 2).138

caption.p: Levels of Evidence for Therapeutic Studies139

tr.th: Therapeutic Studies Investigating Results of Treatment

tr.td: High-quality randomized trials with statistically significant difference or no statistically significant difference but narrow confidence intervals; systematic reviews of Level I randomized controlled trials (and study results were homogeneous)

Lesser-quality randomized controlled trials (eg, <80% follow-up, no blinding, or improper randomization); prospective comparative studies; systematic reviews of Level II studies or Level I studies with inconsistent results
Case-control studies; retrospective comparative studies; systematic reviews of Level III studies

caption.p: Grades of Recommendation for Summaries or Reviews of Orthopaedic Surgical Studies138

tr.td: Good evidence (level I studies with consistent findings) for or against recommending intervention
Fair evidence (level II or III studies with consistent findings) for or against recommending intervention
Poor-quality evidence (level IV or V studies with consistent findings) for or against recommending intervention
There is insufficient or conflicting evidence not allowing a recommendation for or against intervention.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The grade of recommendation assigned to each intervention is summarized in Table 3. There is poor evidence (grade C) in support of cheilectomy (Tables 4 and 5). There is poor evidence (grade C) in support of osteotomy (Tables 6 and 7). There is insufficient evidence (grade I) for cheilectomy with osteotomy (Table 8). There is fair evidence (grade B) in support of arthrodesis (Tables 9 and 10). There is poor evidence (grade C) in support of implant arthroplasty (Tables 11 and 12). There is poor evidence (grade C) in support of resection arthroplasty (Tables 13 and 14). There is poor evidence (grade C) in support of interpositional arthroplasty (Tables 15 and 16).

caption.p: Summary of Grade of Recommendation For or Against Surgical Intervention for Hallux Rigidus

tr.td: Implant gives excellent results; cheilectomy, good-excellent results.

fn.p: Abbreviations: AOFAS, American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle scale; DF, dorsiflexion; FAAM, Foot Ankle Ability Measure; HVA, hallux valgus angle; N/A, not available; ROM, range of motion (for metatarsophalangeal joint); VAS, visual analogue scale.

caption.p: Studies of Interpositional Arthroplasty: Level IV

sec.title: Levels I-III
sec.p: The highest-quality studies examining the outcomes of cheilectomy were 3 level III studies (Table 4). Pontell and Gudas100 investigated a cheilectomy group (n = 8) and a hinged silastic implant group (n = 14) in a retrospective study, with follow-up ranging from 46 to 86 months (level III). Six patients in the cheilectomy group rated their satisfaction at 90%, while the other 2 rated it as between 90% and 100%. In the implant group, the average patient satisfaction was 98%. The authors did not provide a statistical comparison of the 2 groups. They did, however, conclude that cheilectomy was a good option for patients with grade I hallux rigidus, while the hinged silastic implant was the treatment of choice for patients with grade II or III hallux rigidus.

Keiserman et al66 conducted a retrospective study of a cheilectomy group (n = 14), an arthrodesis group (n = 5), and an interpositional arthroplasty group (n = 3), with an average follow-up of 44.3 months (level III). Cheilectomy was used to treat grade II and III cases of hallux rigidus, as was arthrodesis. Arthroplasty was used only in grade III cases. All groups experienced a significant increase in American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle (AOFAS) score following surgery. The AOFAS score for the cheilectomy group improved from 61.2 preoperatively to 85.5 postoperatively (P < .001). The AOFAS score for the arthrodesis group improved from 52.8 preoperatively to 79.6 postoperatively (P = .007). The AOFAS score for the interpositional arthroplasty group improved from 57.6 preoperatively to 97.3 postoperatively (P = .01). The final AOFAS score of 79.6 for the arthrodesis group represents 88% (79.6/90) of the maximum score of 90 for that procedure. Statistical comparison of postoperative AOFAS scores between groups was not conducted due to low sample numbers.

Beertema et al6 compared cheilectomy (n = 28), arthrodesis (n = 34), and Keller resection arthroplasty (n = 28) groups retrospectively, with an average follow-up of 84 months (level III). Cheilectomy was found to yield significantly better postoperative AOFAS scores compared to arthrodesis (P = .001). Resection arthroplasty was also found to yield significantly better postoperative AOFAS scores compared to arthrodesis (P = .000). There was no significant difference between the cheilectomy and resection arthroplasty groups (P = 1.000). Postoperative AOFAS scores for cheilectomy were 87 and 82 for grade I and II hallux rigidus, respectively. There were no grade III cases. Scores for resection arthroplasty were 94, 83, and 87 and for arthrodesis, 73, 81, and 73 for grades I, II, and III, respectively. Pain was measured using a visual analogue scale (VAS). The VAS score for the cheilectomy group was not significantly different from either of the other groups.

sec.title: Levels IV and V
sec.p: There were 15 level IV studies identified that reviewed cheilectomy (Table 5).* The rates of a good or excellent outcome ranged from a low of 72% (42/58) to a high of 100% (20/20). Of the 15 studies, 11 found good or excellent outcomes in at least 80% of cases, with at least 90% in 9 of 15. There were also 14 level V studies in support of cheilectomy.†

sec.title: Grade of recommendation
sec.p: Based on the previously mentioned literature, the operative procedure of cheilectomy is assigned a grade C recommendation (poor evidence, level IV or V studies with consistent findings) supporting it as an effective treatment for hallux rigidus. In poor-quality comparative studies, there was not consistent evidence that cheilectomy was better than other operative interventions. It should be noted, however, that all procedures were shown to provide good results overall. Therefore, the recommendation must be based on the findings of the level IV and V studies.

sec.title: Levels I-III
sec.p: There were 2 level II studies investigating osteotomy as treatment for hallux rigidus (Table 6). Roukis and Townley108 conducted a prospective comparative study of a periarticular osteotomy group (Austin-Youngswick osteotomy or Green-Watermann osteotomy; n = 16) and a BioPro (BioPro, Inc, Port Huron, Michigan; n = 9) resurfacing endoprosthesis group. The authors did not indicate how many osteotomies were Austin-Youngswick and how many were Green-Watermann. The follow-up for this study was 12 months. The authors stated that there was no significant difference between preoperative and postoperative modified AOFAS scores for the 2 study groups; however, P values for this comparison were not given. The periarticular osteotomy group improved from 54.4 to 84.6, while the endoprosthesis group improved from 51.1 to 77.8. The authors suggested that further, long-term investigation needs to be done before a conclusion can be made.

Kilmartin69 prospectively compared a group treated with a phalangeal osteotomy (n = 49) with a group treated with first metatarsal decompression osteotomy (n = 59; level II). The average follow-up was 29 months in the phalangeal osteotomy group and 15 months in the decompression osteotomy group. The phalangeal osteotomy group improved significantly from a preoperative AOFAS score of 43 to a postoperative score of 88 (P < .001). The first metatarsal decompression osteotomy group improved significantly from 42 preoperatively to 88 postoperatively (P < .001). The author found higher satisfaction rates (65%, 32/49, completely satisfied) and lower dissatisfaction (11%, 5/49) in the phalangeal osteotomy group compared to the first metatarsal decompression osteotomy group (54%, 32/59, completely satisfied; 32%, 19/59, dissatisfied), but these were not statistically significant (P > .05).

sec.title: Levels IV and V
sec.p: There were 12 level IV studies identified that reviewed osteotomy (Table 7).‡ The rates of a good or excellent outcome ranged from a low of 69% to a high of 100% (18/18). Most studies (8 of 12) found good or excellent outcomes in at least 80% of cases. These studies dealt with patients who were mostly grade II or III hallux rigidus. One study found continued long-term satisfaction with osteotomy at an average follow-up of 22 years.20 There were also 6 level V studies in support of osteotomy36,42,47,85,93,135 and 1 against.52

sec.title: Grade of recommendation
sec.p: Based on the previously mentioned literature, the operative procedure of osteotomy is assigned a grade C recommendation (poor evidence, level IV or V studies with consistent findings) supporting it as an effective treatment for hallux rigidus. Neither of the 2 level II studies demonstrated osteotomy to be superior to other operative interventions. They did, however, demonstrate good results for patients treated with osteotomy. The use of osteotomy in the treatment of hallux rigidus is therefore given a grade C recommendation for intervention, based on the findings of the 12 level IV studies.

sec.title: Levels I-III
sec.p: There was 1 level III study looking at cheilectomy with osteotomy as treatment for hallux rigidus (Table 8). Lau and Daniels75 retrospectively compared a group treated with cheilectomy (n = 24) with a group treated with interpositional arthroplasty (n = 11), with an average follow-up of 24 months (level III). In the group treated with cheilectomy, 21 of 24 patients also underwent a dorsal closing-wedge phalangeal osteotomy at the time of operation. The group treated with interpositional arthroplasty had a more advanced stage of hallux rigidus (P < .0001). The authors stated that there was no significant difference in postoperative AOFAS scores, with the cheilectomy-with-osteotomy group scoring 78.0, compared to 71.6 in the interpositional arthroplasty group. They also stated that there was no significant difference in postoperative VAS pain scores, with 2.9 in the cheilectomy-with-osteotomy group and 3.9 in the interpositional arthroplasty group. There was no significant difference in SF-36 scores. P values were not given for these 3 comparisons. The cheilectomy-with-osteotomy group did have a higher level of patient satisfaction, at 88% (21/24), compared with 73% (8/11) in the arthroplasty group.

sec.title: Levels IV and V
sec.p: There were 2 level IV studies identified that reviewed cheilectomy with osteotomy (Table 8).105,127 They found good or excellent outcomes in 64% and 96% (23/24) of cases. There were also 2 level V studies in support of cheilectomy with osteotomy.30,83

sec.title: Grade of recommendation
sec.p: Based on the previously mentioned literature, there is insufficient evidence to make a recommendation. Therefore, the use of cheilectomy with osteotomy in the treatment of hallux rigidus is given a grade I recommendation.

sec.title: Levels I-III
sec.p: There was 1 level I and 4 level III studies examining the efficacy of treating hallux rigidus with arthrodesis (Table 9). Gibson and Thomson48 carried out a randomized controlled trial (RCT) comparing arthrodesis (n = 34) and total metatarsophalangeal arthroplasty (n = 30), with follow-up at 24 months (level I). They found that both interventions significantly reduce pain. Arthrodesis improved the VAS pain score from 62 to 11 (P < .001), while arthroplasty improved this score from 60 to 29 (P < .001). However, arthrodesis provided significantly better pain relief when compared to arthroplasty (P = .01). Arthrodesis also provided significantly higher functional satisfaction among patients, based on subjective feedback at the time of follow-up (P = .002). At the 24-month follow-up, 32 of 34 patients in the arthrodesis group stated that they were satisfied with foot function, compared to 25 of 30 in the implant arthroplasty group. Furthermore, 6 patients in the implant group underwent revision prior to 24 months and were not included in clinical evaluation at 24 months. Arthrodesis had fewer complications and was noted to be a less expensive procedure.

Crymble24 conducted a retrospective study of an arthrodesis group (n = 10) and a resection arthroplasty group (n = 16; level III). The follow-up period was not stated. The study found that patients in the arthroplasty group had shorter hospital stays, faster return to wearing shoes, and faster return to normal activity. There were no statistical comparisons to determine whether these differences were significant. The arthroplasty group also had higher satisfaction (100%, 10/10) compared to the arthrodesis group (94%, 15/16), but these both represent high satisfaction levels.

Raikin et al101 published a retrospective study comparing arthrodesis (n = 27) and metallic hemiarthroplasty (n = 21), with an average follow-up of 79.4 months (level III). They found a significantly better AOFAS score in the arthrodesis group compared to the hemiarthroplasty group (P = .006). The arthrodesis group had a postoperative AOFAS score of 83.8 out of a possible 90 (93.1%), compared to 71.8 out of 100 (71.8%) in the hemiarthroplasty group. There was also a significantly better postoperative VAS pain score in the arthrodesis group, 0.7, compared to the hemiarthroplasty group, 2.4 (P = .021). There was a high revision rate in the hemiarthroplasty group (24%, 5/21), while there were no revisions in the arthrodesis group. Patient satisfaction was significantly higher in the arthrodesis group, at 81% (22/27), compared to the hemiarthroplasty group, at 57% (12/21; P < .01).

As discussed previously, Keiserman et al66 conducted a retrospective study of an arthrodesis group (n = 5), a cheilectomy group (n = 14), and an interpositional arthroplasty group (n = 3; level III). They found a significant increase in AOFAS scores in the arthrodesis group (P = .007) but did not compare between groups due to the low sample numbers.

Also discussed previously, Beertema et al6 compared arthrodesis (n = 34), cheilectomy (n = 28), and Keller resection arthroplasty (n = 28) groups retrospectively (level III). They found arthrodesis to yield significantly lower postoperative AOFAS scores when compared to cheilectomy (P = .001) or resection arthroplasty (P = .000).

sec.title: Levels IV and V
sec.p: There were 14 level IV arthrodesis studies (Table 10).§ There was 1 study with mixed diagnoses that included 1 case of hallux rigidus, which had an unsatisfactory outcome.118 Excluding this study, satisfaction levels ranged from 57% (4/7) to 100% (24/24), with 8 studies finding good to excellent results in at least 80%. In fact, satisfaction in 7 of these 8 studies ranged from 91% (72/79) to 100% (24/24). There were also 18 level V studies in support of arthrodesis.‖

sec.title: Grade of recommendation
sec.p: Based on the previously mentioned literature, the operative procedure of arthrodesis is assigned a grade B recommendation (fair evidence, level II or III studies with consistent findings) supporting it as an effective treatment for hallux rigidus. Arthrodesis was found to produce equivalent or superior results in 4 of the 5 level I-III studies. One level I study and 1 level III study demonstrated significantly better postoperative outcomes.48,101 It should be noted that 1 level III study found inferior results with arthrodesis.6 This outcome was the result of poor findings for early-stage hallux rigidus. This same study showed that arthrodesis was equally efficacious to other options at more advanced stages.

sec.title: Levels I-III
sec.p: There was 1 level I, 1 level II, and 2 level III studies of implant arthroplasty (Table 11). These have all been discussed previously. Gibson and Thomson48 carried out an RCT comparing total replacement arthroplasty (n = 30) and arthrodesis (n = 34; level I). When compared to implant arthroplasty, arthrodesis provided significantly better pain relief (P = .01) and higher functional satisfaction (P = .002).

Roukis and Townley108 conducted a prospective comparative study of a BioPro resurfacing endoprosthesis group (n = 9) and a periarticular osteotomy group (n = 16; level II). They stated that there was no significant difference between preoperative and postoperative modified AOFAS scores for the 2 study groups.

Pontell and Gudas100 investigated a hinged silastic implant group (n = 14) and a cheilectomy group (n = 8) in a retrospective study (level III). They found good results with both groups but did not provide statistical comparison.

Raikin et al101 published a retrospective study comparing metallic hemiarthroplasty (n = 21) and arthrodesis (n = 27; level III). They found a significantly better AOFAS score (P = .006) and VAS pain score (P = .021) in the arthrodesis group compared to the hemiarthroplasty group.

sec.title: Levels IV and V
sec.p: There were 30 level IV studies identified that utilized implant arthroplasty (Table 12).¶ These studies ranged from 57% (4/7) to 100% (32/32) in terms of good or excellent outcomes. Most studies (19 of 30) found good or excellent outcomes in at least 80% of cases, including 10 studies with at least 90%. Many of the studies reported positive outcomes in patient populations with predominantly grade III or grade IV hallux rigidus. Several studies suggest the need for long-term follow-up to evaluate risk of implant loosening. The average follow-up ranged from 3 months to 112.8 months, with 12 studies of at least 60 months. Of these 12 studies, 10 found good or excellent outcomes in at least 85% of cases. There were also 6 level V studies in support of implant arthroplasty1,3,8,36,50,115 and 3 against.28,41,125

sec.title: Grade of recommendation
sec.p: Based on the previously mentioned literature, the operative procedure of arthroplasty (nontissue implant) is assigned a grade C recommendation (poor evidence, level IV or V studies with consistent findings) supporting it as an effective treatment for hallux rigidus. It should be noted that this analysis combines different methods of arthroplasty (excluding resection and interpositional), and when arthroplasty is compared to other interventions, there are mixed results regarding which intervention is superior in level I-III studies. However, the level IV and V studies consistently showed arthroplasty to be an effective operative intervention for hallux rigidus.

sec.title: Levels I-III
sec.p: There were 3 level III studies of resection arthroplasty (Table 13). Schenk et al110 retrospectively compared the Keller resection arthroplasty (n = 30) with the modified oblique Keller capsular interpositional arthroplasty (n = 22), with an average follow-up of 15 months (level III). They did not find any significant difference between the groups (P = .077). Postoperative AOFAS scores were 88 in the resection arthroplasty group and 89 in the interpositional arthroplasty group. Patient satisfaction was 73% (22/30) in the resection arthroplasty group and 77% (17/22) in the interpositional arthroplasty group, which was not statistically significant (P = .932).

As discussed previously, Crymble24 conducted a retrospective study of a resection arthroplasty group (n = 16) and an arthrodesis group (n = 10; level III). The study found high satisfaction levels in both groups, with no statistical comparison conducted.

Also discussed previously, Beertema et al6 compared Keller resection arthroplasty (n = 28), arthrodesis (n = 34), and cheilectomy (n = 28) groups retrospectively (level III). Resection arthroplasty was found to yield significantly better postoperative AOFAS scores compared to arthrodesis (P = .000), and no significant difference when compared to cheilectomy (P = 1.000).

sec.title: Levels IV and V
sec.p: There were 3 level IV studies identified that looked at resection arthroplasty (Table 14).56,74,109 These 3 studies found that good or excellent outcomes were achieved in 75% (24/32), 82% (9/11), and 92% (33/36) of patients. There were also 6 level V studies in support of resection arthroplasty.#

sec.title: Grade of recommendation
sec.p: Based on the previously mentioned literature, the operative procedure of resection arthroplasty is assigned a grade C recommendation (poor evidence, level IV or V studies with consistent findings) supporting it as an effective treatment for hallux rigidus. There were 3 level III studies that all found good results for resection arthroplasty. However, based on these studies, there is insufficient evidence to demonstrate that resection arthroplasty is clearly superior to other interventions. Therefore, the recommendation must be based on the findings of the level IV and V studies.

sec.title: Levels I-III
sec.p: There were 4 level III studies that investigated interpositional arthroplasty (Table 15). As discussed previously, Lau and Daniels75 retrospectively compared a group treated with interpositional arthroplasty (n = 11) to a group treated with cheilectomy (n = 24; level III). The authors stated that there was no significant difference in postoperative AOFAS scores, VAS pain scores, or SF-36 scores. However, they did conclude that interpositional arthroplasty resulted in less reliable outcomes.

Also discussed previously, Keiserman et al66 conducted a retrospective study of an interpositional arthroplasty group (n = 3), an arthrodesis group (n = 5), and a cheilectomy group (n = 14; level III). They found a significant increase in AOFAS scores in the interpositional arthroplasty group (P = .01) but did not compare between groups due to the low sample numbers.

Also discussed previously, Schenk et al110 retrospectively compared the modified oblique Keller capsular interpositional arthroplasty (n = 22) with the Keller resection arthroplasty (n = 30; level III). They found good outcomes in both groups, with no significant difference between the groups (P = .077).

Mackey et al80 retrospectively compared a modified oblique Keller capsular interpositional arthroplasty group (n = 10) with an arthrodesis group (n = 12; level III). The arthrodesis group consisted of multiple diagnoses and was used only as a comparison group for the cases of hallux rigidus treated with interpositional arthroplasty. The average follow-up for the interpositional arthroplasty group was 63 months, compared with 68 months for the arthrodesis group. There was a significantly higher postoperative AOFAS score in the interpositional arthroplasty group, 89.55, compared to the arthrodesis group, 64.48 (P = .006). The interpositional arthroplasty group also had significantly lower peak plantar pressure under the great toe when walking, 33 N/cm2, compared to 67 N/cm2 in the arthrodesis group (P = .007).

sec.title: Levels IV and V
sec.p: There were 16 level IV studies identified that investigated interpositional arthroplasty (Table 16).** These studies ranged from 65% (20/31) to 100% (13/13) in terms of good or excellent outcomes. Eleven of 16 studies reported good or excellent outcomes in at least 80% of cases, with 7 of the 16 reporting 100% satisfaction. There was also 1 level V study in support of interpositional arthroplasty.92

sec.title: Grade of recommendation
sec.p: Based on the previously mentioned literature, the operative procedure of interpositional arthroplasty is assigned a grade C recommendation (poor evidence, level IV or V studies with consistent findings) supporting it as an effective treatment for hallux rigidus. There was 1 level III study that found interpositional arthroplasty to be a significantly better intervention, but the comparison group contained mixed diagnoses, not exclusively hallux rigidus. The other level III studies found good results with all interventions. Therefore, the recommendation is based on the findings of the level IV and V studies.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This review provides some insight into which operative options for hallux rigidus are supported by current literature. In general terms, all interventions reviewed here for the treatment of hallux rigidus have literature to support their efficacy. There is no operative procedure that may be assigned a grade A recommendation (good evidence, level I studies with consistent findings for or against recommending intervention). Some operative procedures have better evidence supporting their efficacy in treatment of hallux rigidus (arthrodesis better than cheilectomy, osteotomy, implant arthroplasty, resection arthroplasty, and interpositional arthroplasty), while cheilectomy with osteotomy has insufficient evidence to make a conclusion.

The majority of evidence available in level I-III studies is based on the AOFAS Clinical Rating Scale. This is an unvalidated rating system used by most of the primary studies that, admittedly, detracts from the ability of this review to make recommendations based on these results. Furthermore, since the AOFAS scale includes a component score for range of motion, it is a poor choice for comparison of procedures that eliminate motion (ie, arthrodesis) to procedures that preserve motion. Some studies attempted to address this issue by removing the range-of-motion component from the denominator of the arthrodesis score and looking at the AOFAS as a percentage of the maximum achievable score.

Another limitation of this review is that some studies determined the treatment by the severity of hallux rigidus and are therefore biased in operative selection and inclusion. This means that joint-sparing procedures were used for less severe cases of hallux rigidus while joint destructive procedures were used in more advanced stages. This may distort the results, as one would expect patients with less advanced hallux rigidus to have a higher level of function postoperatively, independent of their mode of treatment. Ideally, a review would look at treatment outcomes for each stage of preoperative diagnosis. An additional potential source of bias is the inclusion of studies of implants conducted by implant designers, namely Townley. This includes 1 level II study that identified similar outcomes between osteotomy and nontissue implant106 and 1 level IV study that found good results with nontissue implant.124

The majority of evidence in the literature is based on level III, IV, or V studies, with only a few level I or II studies. There are no consistent findings in comparative studies that are properly powered with validated and appropriate outcome measures to allow any definitive conclusions on which procedure is best. However, the grade B recommendation assigned to arthrodesis may make it the logical leading candidate for future high-quality RCTs. Clearly, further studies—ideally, high-quality level I RCTs to compare arthrodesis to other interventions discussed in this review—are needed to allow stronger recommendations to be made. The use of more validated outcome measures, such as the Medical Outcomes Study SF-36 and Foot Function Index, would allow stronger recommendations to be made.14,63,89,122

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Based on the results of this review, there is fair evidence (grade B) in support of arthrodesis for treatment of hallux rigidus. There is poor evidence (grade C) in support of cheilectomy, osteotomy, implant arthroplasty, resection arthroplasty, and interpositional arthroplasty for treatment of hallux rigidus. There is insufficient evidence (grade I) for cheilectomy with osteotomy for treatment of hallux rigidus.
